elements.content: Alkali–manganese­(II) trifluoroacetates were synthesized, and their potential as single-source precursors for the solid-state and solution-phase synthesis of AMnF3 fluoroperovskites (A = Na, K, Rb, Cs) was demonstrated. Crystals of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 (tfa = trifluoroacetato) were grown via solvent evaporation and their crystal structures solved using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Chemical purity was confirmed using thermal analyses (TGA/DTA) and Rietveld analysis of powder XRD patterns. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 in both the solid state and solution phase yielded crystalline, single-phase NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites, respectively. Nanocrystals (<100 nm) and submicrocrystals (<500 nm) were obtained in a mixture of high-boiling-point organic solvents. Crystal structures of bimetallic trifluoroacetates displayed a variety of building blocks, coordination environments of the alkali atoms, and coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligand. Alkali–fluorine interactions ranging from chemical bonds to short contacts were observed throughout the series. The coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand was attributed to the ability of the −CF3 groups to interact with alkali atoms over a broad range of distances. The synthetic approach described in this investigation provides a starting point to expand the library of fluorinated single-source precursors suitable for solution-phase routes to mixed-metal fluorides.

elements.content: Mixed-metal fluorides constitute an important family of functional materials in fields such as nonlinear optics, magnetism, superconductivity, and solid electrolytes. Alkali–manganese fluoroperovskites of formula AMnF3 (A = Na, K, Rb, Cs) belong to this family and serve as NIR-to-visible light upconversion hosts, ferromagnets, antiferromagnets, and multiferroics. Despite their relevance as functional materials, low-temperature, solution-phase routes to alkali–manganese fluoroperovskites are currently limited due to the unavailability of suitable precursors. Fluorinated single-source precursors containing the target metal atoms in the desired stoichiometric ratio offer two main advantages over multisource precursors: improved compositional homogeneity and lower decomposition temperature. A comprehensive literature search for bimetallic compounds containing alkali-metal atoms (excluding lithium) and fluorinated ligands (alkoxides, carboxylic acids, and diketones) retrieves only two complexes featuring Na–Mn and K–Mn as metal centers: NaMn­(hfac)3 and KMn­(hfa)3 (hfa = hexafluoroacetylacetonate). Furthermore, the potential of both complexes as single-source precursors for the corresponding fluoroperovskites was demonstrated in the solid state (synthesis of bulk NaMnF3) and in the gas phase (chemical vapor deposition of KMnF3 films) but not in solution. Other bimetallic compositions encountered in our literature search include Na–Mg, Na–Ba, Na–Ni, Na–Cu, Na–Zr, Na–Ln (Ln = Y, rare earth), K–Mg, K–Sr, K–Ba, K–Fe, K–Cu, K–Ln, Rb–Ni, Cs–Ni, and Cs–Ln. Similar to what was observed for bimetallic Na–Mn and K–Mn complexes, none of these were investigated as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides; Na–Ln fluorinated complexes are the only exception. It follows from this literature survey that the library of fluorinated single-source precursors for the low-temperature, solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides remains extremely limited.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Mixed-metal fluorides constitute an important family of functional materials in fields such as nonlinear optics, magnetism, superconductivity, and solid electrolytes. Alkali-manganese fluoroperovskites of formula AMnF3 (A = Na, K, Rb, Cs) belong to this family and serve as NIR-to-visible light upconversion hosts, ferromagnets, antiferromagnets, and multiferroics. Despite their relevance as functional materials, low-temperature, solution-phase routes to alkali-manganese fluoroperovskites are currently limited due to the unavailability of suitable precursors. Fluorinated single-source precursors containing the target metal atoms in the desired stoichiometric ratio offer two main advantages over multisource precursors: improved compositional homogeneity and lower decomposition temperature. A comprehensive literature search for bimetallic compounds containing alkali-metal atoms (excluding lithium) and fluorinated ligands (alkoxides, carboxylic acids, and diketones) retrieves only two complexes featuring Na-Mn and K-Mn as metal centers: NaMn(hfac)3  and KMn(hfa)3  (hfa = hexafluoroacetylacetonate). Furthermore, the potential of both complexes as single-source precursors for the corresponding fluoroperovskites was demonstrated in the solid state (synthesis of bulk NaMnF3) and in the gas phase (chemical vapor deposition of KMnF3 films) but not in solution. Other bimetallic compositions encountered in our literature search include Na-Mg, Na-Ba, Na-Ni, Na-Cu, Na-Zr, Na-Ln (Ln = Y, rare earth), K-Mg, K-Sr, K-Ba, K-Fe, K-Cu, K-Ln, Rb-Ni, Cs-Ni, and Cs-Ln. Similar to what was observed for bimetallic Na-Mn and K-Mn complexes, none of these were investigated as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides; Na-Ln fluorinated complexes are the only exception. It follows from this literature survey that the library of fluorinated single-source precursors for the low-temperature, solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides remains extremely limited.

elements.content: This investigation aims at bridging this materials gap by synthesizing bimetallic fluorinated precursors containing alkali metals and divalent manganese and demonstrating their potential as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites. We hypothesized that the trifluoroacetato ligand (tfa) serves the purpose of linking alkali and manganese­(II) to produce bimetallic trifluoroacetates featuring the desired 1:1 stoichiometric ratio. Further, we hypothesized that thermal decomposition of these trifluoroacetates in solution under an inert atmosphere yields crystalline single-phase fluoroperovskites. To test this hypothesis, crystals containing Na:Mn, K:Mn, Rb:Mn, and Cs:Mn in a 1:1 ratio were grown via evaporation of a solvent mixture consisting of water and trifluoroacetic acid (tfaH). Single-crystal structures of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 were solved using X-ray diffraction (XRD). The chemical purity of the polycrystalline samples was probed using thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) and Rietveld analysis of powder XRD data. The potential of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 as single-source precursors for NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites, respectively, was investigated in both the solid state and solution phase. The morphology of fluoroperovskite nano- and submicrocrystals obtained upon thermal decomposition in the solution phase was analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligand to the metal centers were classified according to their bridge index, denticity, and ligating atoms; special emphasis was placed on identifying modes involving alkali–fluorine interactions. On the basis of these findings, the coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand is highlighted from the perspective of utilizing our synthetic strategy to expand the library of fluorinated single-source precursors suitable for solution-phase routes to mixed-metal fluorides.

elements.content: Na2CO3 (99.5%, Sigma Aldrich), K2CO3 (99%, Sigma Aldrich), Rb2CO3 (99.8%, Sigma Aldrich), Cs2CO3 (99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), MnCO3 (99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), and anhydrous CF3COOH (tfaH, 99%, Sigma Aldrich) were used as received. Double-distilled water was employed as the solvent. A mixture of 3 mL of double-distilled water and 3 mL of tfaH was prepared in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask. Stoichiometric amounts of A2CO3 (0.5 mmol) and MnCO3 (1 mmol) were added to this solution. Brownish, transparent solutions were obtained upon quantitative dissolution of the metal carbonates. Crystallization of alkali–manganese bimetallic trifluoroacetates was accomplished by solvent evaporation, which was induced by flowing dry nitrogen gas over the precursor solution. Reaction flasks were immersed in a sand bath, and solvent evaporation took place at 65 °C for 2 days (Na, Rb, Cs) and 30 °C for 5 days (K). A needle-valve rotameter was employed to regulate the nitrogen flow rate, which was maintained constant at 200 mL min–1 in all cases. Polycrystalline solids were obtained and kept under a static nitrogen atmosphere. Single crystals were recovered from the powders for structure determination.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Crystal Growth of Bimetallic Trifluoroacetates

Na2CO3 (99.5%, Sigma Aldrich), K2CO3 (99%, Sigma Aldrich), Rb2CO3 (99.8%, Sigma Aldrich), Cs2CO3 (99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), MnCO3 (99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), and anhydrous CF3COOH (tfaH, 99%, Sigma Aldrich) were used as received. Double-distilled water was employed as the solvent. A mixture of 3 mL of double-distilled water and 3 mL of tfaH was prepared in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask. Stoichiometric amounts of A2CO3 (0.5 mmol) and MnCO3 (1 mmol) were added to this solution. Brownish, transparent solutions were obtained upon quantitative dissolution of the metal carbonates. Crystallization of alkali-manganese bimetallic trifluoroacetates was accomplished by solvent evaporation, which was induced by flowing dry nitrogen gas over the precursor solution. Reaction flasks were immersed in a sand bath, and solvent evaporation took place at 65 °C for 2 days (Na, Rb, Cs) and 30 °C for 5 days (K). A needle-valve rotameter was employed to regulate the nitrogen flow rate, which was maintained constant at 200 mL min-1 in all cases. Polycrystalline solids were obtained and kept under a static nitrogen atmosphere. Single crystals were recovered from the powders for structure determination.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD analysis was carried out using a Bruker X8 Apex single-crystal diffractometer. Colorless crystals with approximate dimensions 0.38 × 0.20 × 0.20 mm (Na), 0.48 × 0.30 × 0.18 mm (K), 0.34 × 0.09 × 0.06 mm (Rb), and 0.39 × 0.35 × 0.08 mm (Cs) were selected for structure determination and mounted in Paratone N oil or epoxy. The deliquescent nature of the potassium–manganese sample required special handling: crystals were mixed with Paratone oil in a glovebox prior to mounting. X-ray intensities were measured at 100 K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Frames were integrated using the Bruker SAINT software. Experimental data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and absorption effects; for the latter, the multiscan method was employed using Bruker SADABS software. Crystal structures were solved using a dual-space approach as implemented in SHELXT and difference Fourier maps as embedded in the SHELXL-2014/7 software running under ShelXle. Structures were visualized using the VESTA software. Hydrogen atom positions were observed within the first 20 unexplained difference electron density maxima in ΔF maps, and refined (i) riding on the parent O atom for tfaH ligands in Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O or (ii) with restrained O–H bond distances (0.83(2) Å) and H–O–H angles (1.33(4) Å H···H distance) in the case of water molecules in K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O. In all cases, the isotropic displacement parameter (U iso H) for the hydrogen atom was constrained according to U iso H = 1.5U eq O, where U eq O is the equivalent isotropic displacement parameter of the parent oxygen atom. summarizes crystal data for Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3; full details on the data collection and structure refinements are given in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. Crystal data were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with numbers 1553450 (Na), 1553451 (K), 1553452 (Rb), and 1553557 (Cs). Additional structural details are given in Tables S2–S16 and Figures S1–S4 in the Supporting Information.

Powder XRD patterns were collected using a Bruker daVinci powder diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was employed. Diffractograms for Rietveld analysis were collected in the 10–70° 2θ range using a step size of 0.010° and a step time of 3 s. Diffractograms for qualitative analysis were collected in the 10–60° 2θ range using a step size of 0.024° and a step time of 0.5 s.

Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder XRD patterns were collected using a Bruker daVinci powder diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was employed. Diffractograms for Rietveld analysis were collected in the 10-70° 2θ range using a step size of 0.010° and a step time of 3 s. Diffractograms for qualitative analysis were collected in the 10-60° 2θ range using a step size of 0.024° and a step time of 0.5 s.

elements.content: Rietveld analysis of powder XRD patterns was conducted using the general structure analysis system (GSAS) with the graphical user interface (EXPGUI) software. The following parameters were refined: (1) scale factor, (2) background, which was modeled using a shifted Chebyschev polynomial function, (3) peak shape, which was modeled using a modified Thompson–Cox–Hasting pseudo-Voight function, (4) lattice constants, (5) atomic coordinates of each metal atom, (6) atomic coordinates of the trifluoroacetato groups, with each group considered as a rigid body, (7) an isotropic displacement parameter (U iso) for each metal atom, (8) an isotropic displacement parameter for each atom belonging to a trifluoroacetato group (Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O) or for each trifluoroacetato group as a whole (CsMn­(tfa)3), (9) site occupancies for fluorine atoms belonging to rotationally disordered −CF3 groups, (10) atomic coordinates of coordinated water molecules, with each molecule considered as a rigid body, and (11) an isotropic displacement parameter for oxygen and hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules, with the constraint that U iso H = 1.5U iso O. Difference curves and R wp and χ 2 residuals were employed to assess the quality of the refined structural models.
elements.clean_text:
Rietveld Analysis

Rietveld analysis of powder XRD patterns was conducted using the general structure analysis system (GSAS) with the graphical user interface (EXPGUI) software. The following parameters were refined: (1) scale factor, (2) background, which was modeled using a shifted Chebyschev polynomial function, (3) peak shape, which was modeled using a modified Thompson-Cox-Hasting pseudo-Voight function, (4) lattice constants, (5) atomic coordinates of each metal atom, (6) atomic coordinates of the trifluoroacetato groups, with each group considered as a rigid body, (7) an isotropic displacement parameter (U iso) for each metal atom, (8) an isotropic displacement parameter for each atom belonging to a trifluoroacetato group (Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O) or for each trifluoroacetato group as a whole (CsMn(tfa)3), (9) site occupancies for fluorine atoms belonging to rotationally disordered -CF3 groups, (10) atomic coordinates of coordinated water molecules, with each molecule considered as a rigid body, and (11) an isotropic displacement parameter for oxygen and hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules, with the constraint that U iso H = 1.5U iso O. Difference curves and R wp and χ 2  residuals were employed to assess the quality of the refined structural models.

An ∼5–20 mg portion of the sample was heated at 35 °C for 30 min under flowing nitrogen (20 mL min–1), and then the temperature was ramped to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Decomposition

Thermal Analysis

Simultaneous thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses were conducted using an SDT2960 TGA-DTA analyzer (TA Instruments). An ~5-20 mg portion of the sample was heated at 35 °C for 30 min under flowing nitrogen (20 mL min-1), and then the temperature was ramped to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: Fluoroperovskite nano- and submicrocrystals were synthesized by thermally decomposing polycrystalline trifluoroacetate precursors in a mixture of oleic acid (OA), oleylamine (OM), and 1-octadecene (ODE). Oleic acid (90%, Sigma Aldrich), oleylamine (70%, Sigma Aldrich), and 1-octadecene (90%, Sigma Aldrich) were used as received. Standard Schlenk line manipulations were followed throughout. In a typical synthesis, 10 mL of the solvent mixture was added to the 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask containing the bimetallic trifluoroacetate precursor. The reaction mixture was heated at 115 °C under vacuum (∼2 mTorr) with vigorous magnetic stirring for 1 h. The atmosphere was switched back to nitrogen, a thermocouple was placed inside the flask in direct contact with the reaction mixture, and the temperature was increased to 275–300 °C. Heating was stopped after 1–3 h, and the reaction mixture was quenched to room temperature using a stream of air. The resulting crystals were precipitated with excess ethanol, centrifuged at 8000 rpm, resuspended in a minimum amount of toluene or hexane, and reprecipitated using a methanol–ethanol mixture. Centrifugation at 8000 rpm followed by drying at room temperature under vacuum yielded white or off-white powders consisting of fluoroperovskite crystals. Details on the composition of the solvent mixture (OA/OM/ODE v/v/v), synthesis temperature, and synthesis time are as follows: (1) NaMnF3, 2/0/8, 275 °C, 1 h; (2) KMnF3, 1/1/8, 300 °C, 1 h; (3) RbMnF3, 1/1/8, 275 °C, 2 h; (4) CsMnF3, 1/1/8, 275 °C, 3 h.

Solution-Phase Decomposition

Synthesis of Nano- and Submicrocrystals

Fluoroperovskite nano- and submicrocrystals were synthesized by thermally decomposing polycrystalline trifluoroacetate precursors in a mixture of oleic acid (OA), oleylamine (OM), and 1-octadecene (ODE). Oleic acid (90%, Sigma Aldrich), oleylamine (70%, Sigma Aldrich), and 1-octadecene (90%, Sigma Aldrich) were used as received. Standard Schlenk line manipulations were followed throughout. In a typical synthesis, 10 mL of the solvent mixture was added to the 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask containing the bimetallic trifluoroacetate precursor. The reaction mixture was heated at 115 °C under vacuum (~2 mTorr) with vigorous magnetic stirring for 1 h. The atmosphere was switched back to nitrogen, a thermocouple was placed inside the flask in direct contact with the reaction mixture, and the temperature was increased to 275-300 °C. Heating was stopped after 1-3 h, and the reaction mixture was quenched to room temperature using a stream of air. The resulting crystals were precipitated with excess ethanol, centrifuged at 8000 rpm, resuspended in a minimum amount of toluene or hexane, and reprecipitated using a methanol-ethanol mixture. Centrifugation at 8000 rpm followed by drying at room temperature under vacuum yielded white or off-white powders consisting of fluoroperovskite crystals. Details on the composition of the solvent mixture (OA/OM/ODE v/v/v), synthesis temperature, and synthesis time are as follows: (1) NaMnF3, 2/0/8, 275 °C, 1 h; (2) KMnF3, 1/1/8, 300 °C, 1 h; (3) RbMnF3, 1/1/8, 275 °C, 2 h; (4) CsMnF3, 1/1/8, 275 °C, 3 h.

elements.content: TEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM2010F (JEOL Ltd.) electron microscope operated at 200 kV. Specimens were prepared by diluting the native solution with toluene and drop-casting the resulting suspension on a 200 mesh Cu grid coated with a lacey-carbon film (Ted Pella Inc.).

Transmission Electron Imaging (TEM)

TEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM2010F (JEOL Ltd.) electron microscope operated at 200 kV. Specimens were prepared by diluting the native solution with toluene and drop-casting the resulting suspension on a 200 mesh Cu grid coated with a lacey-carbon film (Ted Pella Inc.).

elements.content: Crystal structures of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 are depicted in . Extended views (a–d), building blocks (e–h), and coordination environments of the alkali atoms (i–o) are shown for each compound. All four bimetallic trifluoroacetates feature a 1:1 alkali-to-manganese ratio, which is highly desirable from the standpoint of using them as precursors for NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites. Coordinated solvent molecules (i.e., tfaH and/or water) are present in Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O. Both Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and CsMn­(tfa)3 are anhydrous, despite the fact that water was present during crystal growth; a similar observation was reported for monometallic Sr­(tfa)2 and Ba­(tfa)2 crystallized via solvent evaporation under an inert atmosphere. Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O in monoclinic P21/c, and CsMn­(tfa)3 in tetragonal I41/a. A different crystal packing motif is observed for each member of the series (a–d). The building block of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) consists of a finite, zigzag chain of Mn2–Na1–Mn1–Na2–Na2–Mn1–Na1–Mn2 edge-sharing polyhedra (e). Three-dimensional connectivity is achieved by connecting neighboring chains through bridging carboxylate groups. K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, in contrast, shows two-dimensional connectivity, a feature observed only for this compound. The structure consists of double layers stacked along the a axis; these are held together by dispersion forces between the −CF3 groups, which decorate the interlayer gap. The building block of each layer is an infinite, zigzag chain of alternating −K1–Mn1–K2–Mn2– edge- and face-sharing polyhedra (f). Neighboring chains are connected through bridging carboxylate ligands. In the case of, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, the basic building block is a cluster of Rb2–Mn2–Mn1–Rb1–Rb2–Mn2–Mn1–Rb1 corner-, edge-, and face-sharing polyhedra (g). Each cluster is connected to its neighbors through bridging carboxylate ligands. Finally, the structure of CsMn­(tfa)3 consists of helical chains of corner-sharing cesium–oxygen–fluorine polyhedra running parallel to the c axis (h); infinite chains of carboxylate-bridged manganese–oxygen octahedra are surrounded by these helical chains.

Results and Discussion

Extended views (a-d), building blocks (e-h), and coordination environments of the alkali atoms (i-o) are shown for each compound. All four bimetallic trifluoroacetates feature a 1:1 alkali-to-manganese ratio, which is highly desirable from the standpoint of using them as precursors for NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites. Coordinated solvent molecules (i.e., tfaH and/or water) are present in Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O. Both Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and CsMn(tfa)3 are anhydrous, despite the fact that water was present during crystal growth; a similar observation was reported for monometallic Sr(tfa)2 and Ba(tfa)2 crystallized via solvent evaporation under an inert atmosphere. Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O in monoclinic P21/c, and CsMn(tfa)3 in tetragonal I41/a. A different crystal packing motif is observed for each member of the series (a-d). The building block of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) consists of a finite, zigzag chain of Mn2-Na1-Mn1-Na2-Na2-Mn1-Na1-Mn2 edge-sharing polyhedra (e). Three-dimensional connectivity is achieved by connecting neighboring chains through bridging carboxylate groups. K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, in contrast, shows two-dimensional connectivity, a feature observed only for this compound. The structure consists of double layers stacked along the a axis; these are held together by dispersion forces between the -CF3 groups, which decorate the interlayer gap. The building block of each layer is an infinite, zigzag chain of alternating -K1-Mn1-K2-Mn2- edge- and face-sharing polyhedra (f). Neighboring chains are connected through bridging carboxylate ligands. In the case of, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O, the basic building block is a cluster of Rb2-Mn2-Mn1-Rb1-Rb2-Mn2-Mn1-Rb1 corner-, edge-, and face-sharing polyhedra (g). elements.content: A description and understanding of metal–ligand interactions in alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates can be approached from two complementary perspectives: focusing on the metal center or on the trifluoroacetato ligand. From the standpoint of the coordination environment of manganese, no major variations are observed upon changing the alkali metal. All four trifluoroacetates contain manganese atoms coordinated by six oxygen atoms in an octahedral geometry. In contrast, alkali atoms are coordinated by both oxygen and fluorine and their geometrical arrangement cannot be described in terms of regular polyhedra. An additional complication to define the alkali coordination environment is the fact that metal–fluorine distances range from actual chemical bonds to short contacts; this is not unusual in metal–organic compounds featuring metal···FC interactions. Any bond length threshold set for defining coordination environments will be arbitrary. Individual evaluation of alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates synthesized in this work led us to consider oxygen and fluorine atoms within 3 (Na), 3.3 (K), 3.6 (Rb), and 3.7 Å (Cs) of the metal center as part of the coordination environment. Metal–oxygen and metal–fluorine distances given in were selected using these threshold values; a similar remark applies to the corresponding coordination environments depicted in i–o. Distances thus obtained are within the ranges reported in the literature for alkali-metal–organic compounds containing fluorinated ligands (for example: Na–F in (i) NaMg­(PFTB)3(thf)3 2.542–2.891 Å, (ii) NaOC­(CF3)­(CH3)2 2.635–3.726 Å, (iii) NaY­(hfac)4 2.90 Å, (iv) [Na­(triglyme)2]­[Y2(TFA)7(THF)2] 2.700 Å, and (v) Na4(tfa)4(diglyme) 2.729–3.043 Å; K–F in (i) KMg­(PFTB)3(thf)­(toluene) 2.817–3.163 Å, (ii) KH­(tfa)2 2.962 Å, and (iii) KMn­(hfa)3 3.11–3.37 Å; Rb–F in (i) RbH­(tfa)2 3.10–3.45 Å and (ii) Rb­[(CF3SO2)­CH] 3.263–3.438 Å; Cs–F in (i) Cs­[Ni3(μ3-F)­(tfa)6(tfaH)3] 3.203–3.558 Å, (ii) CsH­(tfa)2 3.30 Å, and (iii) Cs­(hfac) 3.255–3.722 Å). Bond length threshold values utilized in this work are remarkably close to those employed by Plenio to systematically analyze the coordination chemistry of the CF unit in metal–organic compounds in the solid state. Taking the sum of the ionic van der Waals radii for the alkali metals and the van der Waals radius of fluorine, Plenio set 3.07 (Na), 3.47 (K), 3.67 (Rb), and 3.87 Å (Cs) as bond length thresholds. Inspection of the coordination environment of Na1 in Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) shows it is coordinated by four trifluoroacetato ligands (one of which is protonated) that use both oxygen and fluorine as ligating atoms (i). Coordination of the alkali metal by a trifluoroacetato through an oxygen and a fluorine donor is also encountered in Na2 (j), K1 and K2 atoms in K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O (k,l), Rb1 and Rb2 in Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O (m,n), and Cs in CsMn­(tfa)3 (o). Likewise, trifluoracetato groups ligated through the oxygen donor only are observed throughout the series (Na2, K1, K2, Rb1, and Cs). In contrast, trifluoroacetato coordination using fluorine as the sole ligating atom is observed for the largest alkali metals only: namely, rubidium (Rb1 and Rb2) and cesium. This observation highlights the well-documented significance of metal–fluorine interactions to stabilize large metal centers through coordinative and/or steric saturation. Finally, it is worth noting that in the cases of sodium–, rubidium–, and cesium–manganese compounds alkali atoms are coordinated by four oxygen atoms. In contrast, potassium atoms K1 and K2 are both coordinated by six oxygen atoms. One of these oxygen atoms belongs to a coordinated water molecule that bridges K2 and Mn2 atoms; coordination of water to the alkali atom is not observed in the case of rubidium. Both observations further highlight that the crystal chemistry of K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O deviates sharply from that of the other members of the series.

Analysis of metal–ligand interactions focusing on the trifluoroacetato ligand reveals as many as 10 different coordination modes; these are summarized in and feature differences in bridge index (μ), denticity, and ligating atoms (κ). Coordination modes include bridging, bridging–chelating, monodentate, and bidentate. The ability of the trifluoroacetato ligand to bridge four metal centers has rarely been reported. However, μ4-trifluoroacetato ligands are present in all four alkali–manganese compounds synthesized in this work (Na, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O′,κ2 O′,F′; K, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O′,κ3 O′,F′,F″; Rb and Cs, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O′,κ1 O′). K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O exhibits the largest number of distinct coordination modes (six vs four for Na and Rb and two for Cs). In this compound, only two of the seven distinct trifluoroacetato ligands coordinate to the metal center in the same fashion. Interestingly, one coordination mode (μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O′,κ3 O′,F′,F″) involves the interaction of the potassium with one oxygen and two fluorine atoms, a feature encountered only in this compound. Both observations are in line with the distinct crystal chemistry exhibited by K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O. The multiplicity of coordination modes observed in alkali–manganese compounds highlights the versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand to bridge mono- and divalent cations spanning a broad range of sizes. Being a weaker Lewis base than hydrogen-substituted acetates, trifluoroacetato can easily adapt its coordination mode to accommodate the electronic and steric requirements of the metal center it is coordinated to. Further, the multiplicity of coordination modes shown in , along with the broad range of metal–fluorine distances given in , indicate that the ability of the −CF3 group to regulate the strength of its interaction(s) with the metal center(s) significantly contributes to the flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand. This finding is in line with that of Buchanan et al., who demonstrated the relevance of metal–fluorine interactions to stabilize alkali–alkaline-earth perfluoro-tert-butoxides by providing coordinative saturation of the alkali cation. The coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand provides the basis to extend the synthetic strategy described in this work to a broader scope of mixed-metal fluorides. Preliminary studies show that, indeed, this ligand can be employed to bridge alkali and alkaline-earth atoms and late 3d divalent metal cations.
elements.clean_text: Analysis of metal-ligand interactions focusing on the trifluoroacetato ligand reveals as many as 10 different coordination modes; these are summarized in  and feature differences in bridge index (μ), denticity, and ligating atoms (κ). Coordination modes include bridging, bridging-chelating, monodentate, and bidentate. The ability of the trifluoroacetato ligand to bridge four metal centers has rarely been reported. However, μ4-trifluoroacetato ligands are present in all four alkali-manganese compounds synthesized in this work (Na, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O',κ2 O',F'; K, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O',κ3 O',F',F"; Rb and Cs, μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O',κ1 O'). K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O exhibits the largest number of distinct coordination modes (six vs four for Na and Rb and two for Cs). In this compound, only two of the seven distinct trifluoroacetato ligands coordinate to the metal center in the same fashion. Interestingly, one coordination mode (μ4:κ2 O,F,κ1 O,κ1 O',κ3 O',F',F") involves the interaction of the potassium with one oxygen and two fluorine atoms, a feature encountered only in this compound. Both observations are in line with the distinct crystal chemistry exhibited by K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O. The multiplicity of coordination modes observed in alkali-manganese compounds highlights the versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand to bridge mono- and divalent cations spanning a broad range of sizes. Being a weaker Lewis base than hydrogen-substituted acetates, trifluoroacetato can easily adapt its coordination mode to accommodate the electronic and steric requirements of the metal center it is coordinated to. Further, the multiplicity of coordination modes shown in , along with the broad range of metal-fluorine distances given in , indicate that the ability of the -CF3 group to regulate the strength of its interaction(s) with the metal center(s) significantly contributes to the flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand. This finding is in line with that of Buchanan et al., who demonstrated the relevance of metal-fluorine interactions to stabilize alkali-alkaline-earth perfluoro-tert-butoxides by providing coordinative saturation of the alkali cation. The coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand provides the basis to extend the synthetic strategy described in this work to a broader scope of mixed-metal fluorides. Preliminary studies show that, indeed, this ligand can be employed to bridge alkali and alkaline-earth atoms and late 3d divalent metal cations.

elements.content: The chemical purity of polycrystalline alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates was probed using Rietveld analysis of powder XRD data. Single-crystal structures were fit to the experimental powder patterns. The deliquescent nature of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O prevented collection of powder XRD patterns for these two compounds; the former deliquesces within a few minutes and the latter within seconds upon exposure to air. Rietveld fits of Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O and CsMn­(tfa)3 are shown in ; the corresponding refined structural parameters are given in the Tables S17 and S18 in the Supporting Information. Visual inspection of the fits indicates that the structural models derived from single-crystal analysis adequately describe the atomic structure of the polycrystalline trifluoroacetates. Further, the single-phase character of Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O is demonstrated, as all diffraction maxima are indexed to this phase; no secondary crystalline phases are observed (a). In the case of CsMn­(tfa)3, diffraction maxima corresponding to a secondary phase are observed in the 18–26° 2θ range (inset, b); their intensities, however, demonstrate that this secondary phase accounts for a minor fraction of the polycrystalline sample.

elements.content: The chemical purity of polycrystalline trifluoroacetates was also probed using thermal analysis. TGA and DTA curves of the four members of the series are shown in . Experimental weight losses of ∼72.2, 71.3, 60.0 and 55.4 wt % are obtained for sodium–, potassium–, rubidium–, and cesium–manganese trifluoroacetates, respectively. These numbers are in excellent agreement with the theoretical weight losses expected for the decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 to the corresponding NaMnF3 (71.5 wt %), KMnF3 (72.8 wt %), RbMnF3 (59.6 wt %), and CsMnF3 (53.5 wt %); powder XRD, confirming, indeed, that these are the decomposition products (vide infra). The agreement between experimental and theoretical weight losses shows that chemical compositions extracted from single-crystal XRD analyses accurately reflect those of the polycrystalline samples. This finding is particularly relevant in the cases of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, whose chemical purity could not be probed using powder XRD. Inspection of the DTA curves shows that alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates undergo a multistep decomposition. Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O exhibit two major weight losses. The first weight loss is assigned to the removal of tfaH and/or water molecules; values of ∼11.4 (Na), 21.6 (K), and 1.30 (Rb) wt % are estimated. Good agreement is observed between these figures and theoretical weight losses expected for the removal of solvent molecules; these are 12.0 (Na), 22.1 (K), and 1.84 (Rb) wt %. The endothermic nature of these reactions gives further support to this assignment. The second weight loss, accompanied by exothermic peaks in the 275–310 °C range, corresponds to the crystallization of the alkali–manganese fluoroperovskite phase. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) is completed at 320 °C, while that of K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 is finished at 300 °C.

elements.content: Thermal analyses also served the purpose of probing the decomposition of the bimetallic trifluoroacetates in the solid state. Powder XRD patterns of the products obtained after heating at 600 °C under flowing nitrogen are shown in . Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 decompose to orthorhombic NaMnF3 (PDF No. 018-1224; Pnma; a = 5.75 Å, b = 8.00 Å, c = 5.55 Å), cubic KMnF3 (PDF No. 017-0116; Pm3̅m; a = 4.19 Å), cubic RbMnF3 (PDF No. 017-0455; Pm3̅m; a = 4.24 Å), and hexagonal CsMnF3 (PDF No. 024-1211; P63/mmc; a = 6.22 Å, c = 15.11 Å), respectively. Decomposition of CsMn­(tfa)3 to CsMnF3 is consistent with the formation of the so-called hexagonal perovskites, where a three-dimensional network of corner-sharing MnF3 octahedra is replaced by face- and corner-sharing polyhedra that allow for a better fit of the large Cs+ cation. All of the diffraction maxima in the powder XRD patterns can be indexed to the corresponding fluoroperovskite phase; no secondary crystalline phases are observed. Therefore, the alkali to manganese ratio in the precursor is preserved in the decomposition product. This finding, along with the chemical purity of polycrystalline Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3, demonstrates that this series of bimetallic trifluoroacetates serve as single-source precursors for the solid-state synthesis of alkali–manganese fluoroperovskites. Bimetallic trifluoroacetates not only deliver the two metal atoms in the desired stoichiometric ratio but also provide the fluorine source.

elements.content: The potential of alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates to serve as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of fluoroperovskite nano- and submicrocrystals was also investigated. Powder XRD patterns and TEM images of the products obtained after thermal decomposition in a mixture of high-boiling-point organic solvents are shown in . Similar to what was observed in the solid state, Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 decompose to the corresponding fluoroperovskite phase. All of the diffraction maxima are indexed to NaMnF3 (PDF No. 018-1224), KMnF3 (PDF No. 017-0116), RbMnF3 (PDF No. 017-0455), and CsMnF3 (PDF No. 024-1211) (a–d). The absence of other crystalline phases implies that the alkali to manganese ratio in the precursor is preserved in the product. TEM analysis shows that crystalline particles in the nanometer (<100 nm) and submicrometer (<500 nm) size regimes are obtained upon thermal decomposition in solution. Crystal growth habits are clearly reflected in the morphology of the products. Decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) yields rectangular platelets of NaMnF3 (aspect ratio, 1.7 ± 0.5; length, 174 ± 57 nm; width, 112 ± 52 nm; e). KMnF3 and RbMnF3 crystals obtained upon decomposing K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, respectively, exhibit isotropic morphologies: cubic in the former (average edge length, 23.2 ± 6.1 nm; f) and spherical in the latter (average diameter, 120 ± 33 nm; g). Finally, decomposition of CsMn­(tfa)3 yields hexagonal platelets (average edge, 140 ± 30 nm; h). Altogether, these findings demonstrate that bimetallic trifluoroacetates crystallized in this work serve as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of alkali–manganese fluoroperovskites.

elements.content: In summary, the utility of the trifluoroacetato ligand to synthesize chemically pure alkali–manganese­(II) bimetallic trifluoroacetates was demonstrated. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 in both the solid state and solution phase demonstrated that these trifluoroacetates serve as single-source precursors for NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites, respectively. Single-phase, nanometer (<100 nm) and submicrometer (<500 nm) fluoroperovskite crystals were obtained upon decomposition in a mixture of high-boiling-point organic solvents. The ability of the −CF3 groups to interact with alkali atoms over a broad range of distances appeared to be significant for the coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand. This finding provides the basis to extend the synthetic approach described in this investigation to a broader scope of metal centers, thereby enabling an expansion of the library of fluorinated single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the utility of the trifluoroacetato ligand to synthesize chemically pure alkali-manganese(II) bimetallic trifluoroacetates was demonstrated. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O, and CsMn(tfa)3 in both the solid state and solution phase demonstrated that these trifluoroacetates serve as single-source precursors for NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3 fluoroperovskites, respectively. Single-phase, nanometer (<100 nm) and submicrometer (<500 nm) fluoroperovskite crystals were obtained upon decomposition in a mixture of high-boiling-point organic solvents. The ability of the -CF3 groups to interact with alkali atoms over a broad range of distances appeared to be significant for the coordination flexibility of the trifluoroacetato ligand. This finding provides the basis to extend the synthetic approach described in this investigation to a broader scope of metal centers, thereby enabling an expansion of the library of fluorinated single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides.

Good agreement is observed between these figures and theoretical weight losses expected for the removal of solvent molecules; these are 12.0 (Na), 22.1 (K), and 1.84 (Rb) wt %. The endothermic nature of these reactions gives further support to this assignment. The second weight loss, accompanied by exothermic peaks in the 275–310 °C range, corresponds to the crystallization of the alkali–manganese fluoroperovskite phase. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) is completed at 320 °C, while that of K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3 is finished at 300 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text: The chemical purity of polycrystalline trifluoroacetates was also probed using thermal analysis. TGA and DTA curves of the four members of the series are shown in . Experimental weight losses of ~72.2, 71.3, 60.0 and 55.4 wt % are obtained for sodium-, potassium-, rubidium-, and cesium-manganese trifluoroacetates, respectively. These numbers are in excellent agreement with the theoretical weight losses expected for the decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O, and CsMn(tfa)3 to the corresponding NaMnF3 (71.5 wt %), KMnF3 (72.8 wt %), RbMnF3 (59.6 wt %), and CsMnF3 (53.5 wt %); powder XRD, confirming, indeed, that these are the decomposition products (vide infra). The agreement between experimental and theoretical weight losses shows that chemical compositions extracted from single-crystal XRD analyses accurately reflect those of the polycrystalline samples. This finding is particularly relevant in the cases of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) and K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, whose chemical purity could not be probed using powder XRD. Inspection of the DTA curves shows that alkali-manganese trifluoroacetates undergo a multistep decomposition. Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, and Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O exhibit two major weight losses. The first weight loss is assigned to the removal of tfaH and/or water molecules; values of ~11.4 (Na), 21.6 (K), and 1.30 (Rb) wt % are estimated. Good agreement is observed between these figures and theoretical weight losses expected for the removal of solvent molecules; these are 12.0 (Na), 22.1 (K), and 1.84 (Rb) wt %. The endothermic nature of these reactions gives further support to this assignment. The second weight loss, accompanied by exothermic peaks in the 275-310 °C range, corresponds to the crystallization of the alkali-manganese fluoroperovskite phase. Thermal decomposition of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH) is completed at 320 °C, while that of K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O, and CsMn(tfa)3 is finished at 300 °C.

cln_elements.content: The variety of topological features observed in the crystal structures of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3: (a–d) extended perspectives (unit cells are depicted with solid lines); (e–h) building blocks; (i–o) coordination environments of alkali atoms. Atom splitting has been omitted for clarity; only major occupancy sites are shown. Hydrogen bonds are depicted with dashed gray lines.

cln_elements.content: Versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand as reflected in the multiplicity of coordination modes encountered in alkali–manganese bimetallic trifluoroacetates. Bridge index (μ), denticity, and ligating atoms (κ) are given for each mode. Different tfa and tfaH ligands belonging to the same compound are identified with letters. Alkali–fluorine interactions are depicted with dashed lines and range from actual chemical bonds to short contacts.

Bridge index (μ), denticity, and ligating atoms (κ) are given for each mode. Different tfa and tfaH ligands belonging to the same compound are identified with letters. Alkali-fluorine interactions are depicted with dashed lines and range from actual chemical bonds to short contacts.

cln_elements.content: Rietveld analysis of Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O (a) and CsMn­(tfa)3 (b), confirming the chemical purity of both polycrystalline samples. Experimental data (×), calculated patterns (red −), and difference curves (blue −) are shown. Tick marks (green |) corresponding to the calculated position of the diffraction maxima are included. Inset in (b): diffraction maxima corresponding to a secondary phase observed in the pattern of CsMn­(tfa)3 are depicted with asterisks.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Rietveld analysis of Rb2Mn2(tfa)6⋅H2O (a) and CsMn(tfa)3 (b), confirming the chemical purity of both polycrystalline samples. Inset in (b): diffraction maxima corresponding to a secondary phase observed in the pattern of CsMn(tfa)3 are depicted with asterisks.

cln_elements.content: Good agreement between experimental and theoretical weight losses confirming the chemical purity of polycrystalline Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3. cln_elements.content: Alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates serving as single-source precursors for the solid-state synthesis of fluoroperovskites. Shown in this figure are the powder XRD patterns of the decomposition products of Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3. All diffraction maxima can be indexed to NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3. Some Miller indices are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Alkali–manganese trifluoroacetates serving as single-source precursors for the solution-phase synthesis of fluoroperovskite nano- and submicrocrystals. Shown in this figure are the powder XRD patterns (a–d) and TEM images (e–h) of the decomposition products of polycrystalline Na2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH), K2Mn2(tfa)6(tfaH)2·H2O, Rb2Mn2(tfa)6·H2O, and CsMn­(tfa)3. All diffraction maxima can be indexed to NaMnF3, KMnF3, RbMnF3, and CsMnF3. Some Miller indices are omitted for clarity. Particle size distribution histograms were obtained after analyzing 300 crystals; for CsMnF3, only regular hexagons were measured.

metadata.title:
Bimetallic Trifluoroacetates as Single-Source Precursors
for Alkali–Manganese Fluoroperovskites
